statement.p: Suppose that as dry air rose its temperature dropped in a linear fashion. The temperature was measured at 900 ft MSL as \displaystyle{15}^{\circ} C and at 2900 ft MSL as \displaystyle{19.2}^{\circ} C.
What is the rate of change of temperature with respect to altitude? Â
Your response may be as a fraction such as 2/1000 or decimal such as 0.002
What does this data imply about the temperature at 0 ft MSL?

solution.p: We want the ratio of temperature drop to altitude increase. \displaystyle\frac{{{19.2}-{15}}}{{{2900}-{900}}}=-{0.0021}

Now that we know that ratio we can use a linear model to find the temperature at sea level. Because the temperature increases (we are going down not up) at a rate of -2.1 per 1000 ft the temperature will be expected to increase \displaystyle{900}{\left(-\frac{{2.1}}{{1000}}\right)}=-{1.89}. That will result in a temperature of \displaystyle{15}\pm{1.89}={13.11}.
